question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M FOUNDATION DIPLOMA ENDTERM QPD1 07 Aug 2022

options.option_text: Useful Data has been mentioned above.
This data attachment is just for a reference & not for an evaluation.

questions.question_text_1: The standard deviation of the length of bolts manufactured by a machine was 1 mm. A new machine with a supposedly lesser standard deviation is installed. A random sample of 100 bolts from the new machine showed a standard deviation of 0.5 mm. Based on this data, what is your conclusion at a significance level of 0.05, on the standard deviation of length of bolts manufactured by the new machine? Choose the correct options from the following (Select all that apply):
question_texts: The standard deviation of the length of bolts manufactured by a machine was 1 mm. A new machine with a supposedly lesser standard deviation is installed. A random sample of 100 bolts from the new machine showed a standard deviation of 0.5 mm. Based on this data, what is your conclusion at a significance level of 0.05, on the standard deviation of length of bolts manufactured by the new machine? Choose the correct options from the following (Select all that apply):

questions.question_text_1: The average life of a battery is 4 years, with a standard deviation of 1 year. Assuming that the lives of the batteries follow approximately a normal distribution, find the probability that the mean life of a random sample of 30 such batteries falls between 3.8 and 4.2 years. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.
question_texts: The average life of a battery is 4 years, with a standard deviation of 1 year. Assuming that the lives of the batteries follow approximately a normal distribution, find the probability that the mean life of a random sample of 30 such batteries falls between 3.8 and 4.2 years. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose the number of deceased people in a week because of a deadly disease in a country has the Poisson(λ) distribution. A researcher wants to estimate λ. From studies in other countries, prior mean should be 3, and the prior standard deviation 1. He decides to use the Gamma(α, β) prior that matches his prior mean and standard deviation. The number of deceased people recorded over the next 10 weeks are: 3, 5, 7, 0, 1, 7, 4, 9, 6, 4.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Suppose the number of deceased people in a week because of a deadly disease in a country has the Poisson(λ) distribution. A researcher wants to estimate λ. From studies in other countries, prior mean should be 3, and the prior standard deviation 1. He decides to use the Gamma(α, β) prior that matches his prior mean and standard deviation. The number of deceased people recorded over the next 10 weeks are: 3, 5, 7, 0, 1, 7, 4, 9, 6, 4.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: The time (in minutes) required to repair electronic gadgets by an electrician is an exponential random variable with unknown parameter λ. Consider a sample (in minutes) 10, 11, 25, 1, 4, 5, 8, 35, 14, 15 from his previous repairing time.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose a principal states that the students studying in her school have an average IQ score equal to 98.5. A reporter suspects that the average may be lower, possibly 98 and took a sample of 100 random students from the school and observed the average IQ score to be 98.29. Assume the IQ scores of the students are normally distributed with standard deviation 1.2.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Suppose a principal states that the students studying in her school have an average IQ score equal to 98.5. A reporter suspects that the average may be lower, possibly 98 and took a sample of 100 random students from the school and observed the average IQ score to be 98.29. Assume the IQ scores of the students are normally distributed with standard deviation 1.2.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts** ### **1. Probability Distributions** #### **Discrete Distributions** | Distribution | PMF (Probability Mass Function) | CDF (Cumulative Distribution Function) | Expectation \(E[X]\) | Variance \(Var(X)\) | |--------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------|----------------------------| | **Uniform** | \(f_X(k) = \frac{1}{n}\), \(k = a, a+1, \ldots, b\)
\(n = b - a + 1\) | \(F_X(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x < a \\ \frac{k-a+1}{n} & k \leq x < k+1 \\ 1 & x \geq b \end{cases}\) | \(\frac{a+b}{2}\) | \(\frac{n^2-1}{12}\) | | **Bernoulli** | \(f_X(k) = \begin{cases} p & k=1 \\ 1-p & k=0 \end{cases}\) | \(F_X(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x < 0 \\ 1-p & 0 \leq x < 1 \\ 1 & x \geq 1 \end{cases}\) | \(p\) | \(p(1-p)\) | | **Binomial** | \(f_X(k) = {}^nC_k p^k (1-p)^{n-k}\), \(k=0,1,\ldots,n\) | \(F_X(x) = \sum_{i=0}^k {}^nC_i p^i (1-p)^{n-i}\) | \(np\) | \(np(1-p)\) | | **Geometric** | \(f_X(k) = (1-p)^{k-1}p\), \(k=1,2,\ldots\) | \(F_X(x) = 1 - (1-p)^k\) | \(\frac{1}{p}\) | \(\frac{1-p}{p^2}\) | | **Poisson** | \(f_X(k) = \frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^k}{k!}\), \(k=0,1,\ldots\) | \(F_X(x) = e^{-\lambda} \sum_{i=0}^k \frac{\lambda^i}{i!}\) | \(\lambda\) | \(\lambda\) | #### **Continuous Distributions** | Distribution | PDF (Probability Density Function) | CDF (Cumulative Distribution Function) | Expectation \(E[X]\) | Variance \(Var(X)\) | |--------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------|----------------------------| | **Uniform** | \(f_X(x) = \frac{1}{b-a}\), \(a \leq x \leq b\) | \(F_X(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x \leq a \\ \frac{x-a}{b-a} & a < x < b \\ 1 & x \geq b \end{cases}\) | \(\frac{a+b}{2}\) | \(\frac{(b-a)^2}{12}\) | | **Exponential** | \(f_X(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}\), \(x > 0\) | \(F_X(x) = 1 - e^{-\lambda x}\) | \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\) | \(\frac{1}{\lambda^2}\) | | **Normal** | \(f_X(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}\) | No closed form | \(\mu\) | \(\sigma^2\) | | **Gamma** | \(f_X(x) = \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma(\alpha)} x^{\alpha-1} e^{-\beta x}\), \(x > 0\) | Not provided | \(\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\) | \(\frac{\alpha}{\beta^2}\) | | **Beta** | \(f_X(x) = \frac{\Gamma(\alpha+\beta)}{\Gamma(\alpha)\Gamma(\beta)} x^{\alpha-1} (1-x)^{\beta-1}\), \(0 < x < 1\) | Not provided | \(\frac{\alpha}{\alpha+\beta}\) | \(\frac{\alpha \beta}{(\alpha+\beta)^2 (\alpha+\beta+1)}\) | --- ### **2. Inequalities & Theorems** | Concept | Equation | |-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Markov’s Inequality** | \(P(X \geq c) \leq \frac{E[X]}{c}\), \(X \geq 0\) | | **Chebyshev’s Inequality** | \(P(|X - \mu| \geq k\sigma) \leq \frac{1}{k^2}\) | | **Weak Law of Large Numbers** | \(P(|\overline{X} - \mu| > \delta) \leq \frac{\sigma^2}{n \delta^2}\) | | **Central Limit Theorem (CLT)** | \(\frac{Y - n\mu}{\sqrt{n}\sigma} \approx \text{Normal}(0,1)\), where \(Y = \sum X_i\) | --- ### **3. Estimation Techniques** | Technique | Key Idea | Equation | |-------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Method of Moments** | Match sample moments to theoretical moments. | \(M_k = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^k\), solve \(E[X^k] = M_k\) for parameters. | | **Maximum Likelihood (ML)** | Maximize likelihood \(L(\theta) = \prod f_X(x_i; \theta)\). | \(\hat{\theta} = \arg \max_\theta L(\theta)\) | | **Bayesian Estimation** | Combine prior \(f_\Theta(\theta)\) and likelihood \(L(\theta)\) to get posterior. | Posterior \(\propto\) Prior \(\times\) Likelihood | | **Bias of Estimator** | \(Bias(\hat{\theta}) = E[\hat{\theta}] - \theta\) | | --- ### **4. Hypothesis Testing** #### **Single Sample Tests** | Test Type | Null Hypothesis \(H_0\) | Alternative \(H_A\) | Test Statistic | Rejection Region | |-------------------------|-------------------------|----------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------| | **Z-test (known \(\sigma^2\))** | \(\mu = \mu_0\) | \(\mu > \mu_0\) (right-tailed) | \(Z = \frac{\overline{X} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}}\) | \(\overline{X} > c\) | | | | \(\mu < \mu_0\) (left-tailed) | | \(\overline{X} < c\) | | | | \(\mu \neq \mu_0\) (two-tailed)| | \(|\overline{X} - \mu_0| > c\) | | **T-test (unknown \(\sigma^2\))** | \(\mu = \mu_0\) | \(\mu > \mu_0\) | \(t_{n-1} = \frac{\overline{X} - \mu_0}{s / \sqrt{n}}\) | \(\overline{X} > c\) | | **Chi-square (\(\sigma^2\))** | \(\sigma = \sigma_0\) | \(\sigma > \sigma_0\) | \(T = \frac{(n-1)S^2}{\sigma_0^2} \sim \chi^2_{n-1}\) | \(S^2 > c^2\) | #### **Two Sample Tests** | Test Type | Null Hypothesis \(H_0\) | Alternative \(H_A\) | Test Statistic | Rejection Region | |-------------------------|-------------------------|----------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------| | **Z-test for means** | \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) | \(\mu_1 > \mu_2\) | \(T = \overline{X} - \overline{Y} \sim \text{Normal}(0, \frac{\sigma_1^2}{n_1} + \frac{\sigma_2^2}{n_2})\) | \(\overline{X} - \overline{Y} > c\) | | **F-test for variances**| \(\sigma_1 = \sigma_2\) | \(\sigma_1 > \sigma_2\) | \(T = \frac{S_1^2}{S_2^2} \sim F_{(n_1-1, n_2-1)}\) | \(\frac{S_1^2}{S_2^2} > 1 + c\) | --- ### **5. Conditional Probability & Joint Distributions** | Concept | Equation | |-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Conditional PMF/PDF** | \(f_{X|Y}(x|y) = \frac{f_{XY}(x,y)}{f_Y(y)}\) | | **Conditional Expectation** | \(E[X|Y=y] = \sum x f_{X|Y}(x|y)\) (discrete) or \(\int x f_{X|Y}(x|y) dx\) (continuous) | | **Marginal Distribution** | \(f_X(x) = \sum_y f_{XY}(x,y)\) (discrete) or \(\int f_{XY}(x,y) dy\) (continuous) | --- ### **6. Bayesian Inference** | Concept | Equation | |-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Prior** | \(f_\Theta(\theta)\) | | **Likelihood** | \(L(\theta) = \prod f_X(x_i; \theta)\) | | **Posterior** | \(f_{\Theta|X}(\theta|x) \propto f_\Theta(\theta) \times L(\theta)\) | | **Posterior Mean (Normal)** | \(\mu = \overline{X} \left( \frac{n \sigma_0^2}{n \sigma_0^2 + \sigma^2} \right) + \mu_0 \left( \frac{\sigma^2}{n \sigma_0^2 + \sigma^2} \right)\) | --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: Probability Distributions** ```mermaid graph TD A[Probability Distributions] --> B[Discrete] A --> C[Continuous] B --> D[Uniform] B --> E[Bernoulli] B --> F[Binomial] B --> G[Geometric] B --> H[Poisson] C --> I[Uniform] C --> J[Exponential] C --> K[Normal] C --> L[Gamma] C --> M[Beta] ``` ### **Graph 2: Estimation Techniques** ```mermaid graph TD A[Estimation] --> B[Point Estimation] A --> C[Interval Estimation] B --> D[Method of Moments] B --> E[Maximum Likelihood] B --> F[Bayesian Estimation] F --> G[Prior] F --> H[Likelihood] F --> I[Posterior] ``` ### **Graph 3: Hypothesis Testing** ```mermaid graph TD A[Hypothesis Testing] --> B[Single Sample] A --> C[Two Sample] B --> D[Z-test] B --> E[T-test] B --> F[Chi-square Test] C --> G[Z-test for Means] C --> H[F-test for Variances] ``` ### **Graph 4: Theorems & Inequalities** ```mermaid graph TD A[Theorems] --> B[Markov's Inequality] A --> C[Chebyshev's Inequality] A --> D[Weak Law of Large Numbers] A --> E[Central Limit Theorem] ``` ### **Graph 5: Conditional Probability** ```mermaid graph TD A[Joint Distributions] --> B[Marginal] A --> C[Conditional] C --> D[Conditional PMF/PDF] C --> E[Conditional Expectation] ``` --- This summary covers **all essential equations, concepts, and relationships** needed for the exam. The Mermaid graphs provide a **visual hierarchy** of topics for quick revision.
